A: The problem is likely due to the encoding of the text. The emojis are not being encoded correctly, which is causing them to appear as strange characters.

You can try to change the encoding of the text to UTF-8 before sending it. Here is how you can do it:

```kotlin
override fun getByteData(): MutableMap<String, FileDataPart> {
    val params = HashMap<String, FileDataPart>()
    params["file"] = FileDataPart(
        "file$rndInt",
        getBytes(finalInputSteam!!)!!,
        "fffff"
    )
    return params
}

override fun getParams(): MutableMap<String, String> {
    val parameters = HashMap<String, String>()
    parameters["text"] = "Your text here".toUtf8String() // Convert the text to UTF-8
    return parameters
}
```

In the above code, `toUtf8String()` is a custom extension function that converts a string to UTF-8 encoded bytes.

```kotlin
fun String.toUtf8String(): String {
    return String(this.toByteArray(Charsets.UTF_8), Charsets.UTF_8)
}
```

This should ensure that the text is encoded correctly and the emojis are displayed correctly on the server side.

Please note that this solution assumes that the server is capable of correctly handling UTF-8 encoded text. If the server is not capable of handling UTF-8, you may need to find a different solution.
